summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Illinois today entered a final judgment against the City of Alton, Illinois and Brant T. Walker, a real estate developer, for violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Chicago, Walker and his company, Sunnybrook LP, sought a court-ordered injunction to halt the development of a $500,000 condominium development in Alton.  The complaint alleges that, in early to mid-2017, a partner of Sunnybrook approached the city and its mayor, Brant Walker, for support for the development.  As alleged in the complaint, the developer agreed to make major changes to the condominium project, including adding 12 units for sale and a percentage of those reserved for veteran applicants.  In a parallel action, the Illinois Attorney General's Office today announced criminal charges against the developer.  On March 21, 2019, the SEC filed an amended complaint against Sunnybrook, alleging violations of Section 17(a)(1) and (3) ofÂ the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10Â of the Exchange Act, and ordering the developer to pay a civil penalty equal to the amount of disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and civil money penalties.   The SEC's investigation, which is continuing, has been conducted by Michael J. Welshhans and Eric R. Werner of the Chicago Regional Office and supervised by C.J. Kerstetter. The litigation will be led by Mr. Werner and Ms. Werner. The SEC appreciates the assistance of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Chicago Office of Inspector General, and the Illinois Secretary of State's Office in this matter. Â The SEC's Office of Investor Education and Advocacy has issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors to check the background of anyone selling or offering them an investment using the free and simple search tool on Investor.gov.Â  The SEC encourages investors to use theÂ SECÂ investor.gov website to quickly identify whether they are registered professionals and to quickly check the backgrounds of people selling them investments using the SECÂ registration tool.  Investors can quickly and easily check whether their investments are subject to SEC approval.  To learn more about investor education and how to spot potential conflicts of interest, see Investor Alert: Investor Education.gov/Investors.govÂ On June 12, 2018, a federal district court in Calumet City, Illinois issued an order requiring investors to submit an application for a building permit by the deadline of June 5, 2018.
